WHAT IS BITCOIN !!!

Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency invented in 2008 by an unknown person or group of people using the name Satoshi Nakamoto and started in 2009 when its implementation was released as open-source software.

It is a decentralized digital currency without a central bank or single administrator that can be sent from user to user on the peer-to-peer bitcoin network without the need for intermediaries. Transactions are verified by network nodes through cryptography and recorded in a public distributed ledger called a blockchain. Bitcoins are created as a reward for a process known as mining. They can be exchanged for other currencies, products, and services. Research produced by the University of Cambridge estimates that in 2017, there were 2.9 to 5.8 million unique users using a cryptocurrency wallet, most of them using bitcoin.

The domain name "bitcoin.org" was registered on 18 August 2008. On 31 October 2008, a link to a paper authored by Satoshi Nakamoto titled Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System was posted to a cryptography mailing list. Nakamoto implemented the bitcoin software as open-source code and released it in January 2009.[ Nakamoto's identity remains unknown..

Have you been scammed by a website, have late payments due, lost payments, and so on? There is a very good chance CRYPTORECOVERYX can recover this money for you. CRYPTORECOVERYX refers to the task of recovery of assets that have been wrongfully taken either stolen, fraudulently misappropriated or otherwise disposed of to remove them from their rightful owner. CRYPTORECOVERYX has three main elementsâ€”identification, redeployment, and divestment.

What they need from you:

The company name and web address, as well as any other information you can provide about the company.

Any information that identifies you as an account owner. Email address, phone number, home address, and any other person information used during sign up, as well as your username and complete name used to sign up for the service. If you have an account number or membership number this is needed as well. All emails you have received from this company in any regard, shape, or manner. The total amount owed to you, along with any proof of such. Invoices, screen shots, emailed admissions from them with promises to pay and so on. Proof of what they owe you is of extreme importance, BUT this does NOT mean they still cannot recover your money for you even with lack of proof. You may not have these records...they do!

They will do a complete investigation on the company. Background check, company status (if they are a licensed company), as well as financial paper work filed with their local agencies. Once they have evidence exposing them as a scam or fraud involved in illegal activity, they will contact them on your behalf. They will discuss your case with them, while also pointing out proof of illegal activity. Once they know they have them, it is usually enough to recover your funds fairly quickly. Bepro simply explained, plain English:

$Bepro, previously Bet Protocol provide the base tech for other companies to build applications such as prediction markets, games and gambling platforms on top of - that is their product/use case.

Look up â€˜code-as-serviceâ€™ this explains it. 

The value of the coin comes from the need to hold and stake the coin in order to access the Bepro network, access to the network allows you to make the applications.

Staking of the token also incentivises people to hold it for monetary reward.

They are trusted by well known players such as Moonbeam, Chainlink, Elrond and more.

They share a founder with Polkamarkets and have just Partnered with Kylin.

They have just announced a code base offering for NFT factories (Non fungible tokens are HUGE right now).

Also, they offer multi chain functionally - you can set up applications on either Ethereum, Polkadot or Binance Chain.

Some of their customers include 
Current customers include @Polkamarkets & @Exeedme

Do your own research but my opinion is that this token is currently massively undervalued.

OK I 'm a newbie, I get supply and demand, as well as a stock price.  Help me explain- If a stock starts at 1 dollar, and there's high demand, then who is the one saying " ok now that everybody wants this stock im going to raise it to 2 dollars? why doesn't the stock just 'run out' at its in initial dollar value when its listed for sale.  There must be an actual formula or something that automatically raise the price from a dollar as people buy. Who is it that's actually observing the pool, and calculating the new price, as more people enter?  Is it a computer algorithm? I mean it's got to be a person or something that raises the price, up or down? I don't know if I am making since? From my point of view, little digits move up or down on my screen faster then any of us can predict, based on volume. I'm thinking there's a fearful/greedy man on the other side of my screen (they, we, wall street, computer robot?) changing the price. You mention the social diversity and perception is unique about the Market, but that's the public now who is the referee for the price changing, because buyers don't want the price to go up, unless they become sellers. Thus a feedback loop is created, due to the fact I can't predict what john doe is going to do with his stock, and the companies reputation.  Ultimately something is determining the price base on several factors, I get the public, and the apparatus, but not the formula and how its used and implemented, as I see market inhale and exhale as it lives and dies.

The bitcoin cycles can be predicted based on history. I understand you will not get an exact date, but a good window is perfectly logical. It has been so for the past decade. Why would you not assume there will be the same phases in the cycle as before? We're definitely going to reach a peak some time this year (potentially early next year) and after the parabolic there will be a bear market. Industry investment will simply dampen the the volatility and/or lengthen the cycles but this is typical of a maturing asset. The low at the tail-end of the market might only be a 50-60% price reduction from peak and that bear market correction will reduce progressively after each cycle until sometime in the long term, the bitcoin volatility will be more or less stable compared to current.

It's pretty simple to avoid all of these:

1. Don't day trade!
2. Do you own research on the project, team, CEO...
3. Do not think of it as buying coins/tokens, think of it as buying part of companies...Warren Buffet style (BTC included)
4. After you made your research buy coins/tokens it and make a plan (hold for #years,  hold till that price...) and follow the progres of project
5. Store coins/tokens of exchange on hard/paper wallet
 
That way you won't even notice all these market manipulations, because you'll know why you invested your money and what is your plan.

But if you check out the monthly pattern, its actually absolutely normal. In fact, between 51000-53000$ is THE best entry point right now.
BUT. If bitcoin falls under 50305$, then bitcoin is likely to go into a longterm downtrend.

Its simple. Higher highs and higher lows = uptrend.
If you think, you're in a downtrend, just zoom out.

"Cardano doesn't have a working product". Yeah, they do. IOHK released their Mary protocol on March 1st, enabling multiasset support. They also just became the first proof-of-stake fully decentralized crypto. That's a huge deal, because they just made DeFi platforms viable and cost-effective. There are real applications.

The Dutch tulip bulb market bubble, also known as 'tulipmania' was one of the most famous marketÂ bubblesÂ and crashes of all time. ItÂ occurred in Holland during the early to midÂ 1600sÂ when speculation drove the value of tulip bulbs to extremes. At the height of the market, the rarest tulip bulbs traded for as much as six times the average person's annual salary.Â 

Today, the tulipmania serves as a parable for the pitfalls that excessive greed and speculation can lead to.

As he says, Elon is a futurist. It now goes against his image to not be invested in the future of money, or digital gold. Also, selling bitcoin would be seen as weakness and uncertainty. The value of Tesla shares hinges on the impression that Elon knows exactly what he intends to do in the future. Clearly, Elon listens to the logic of Saylor and is holding bitcoin long-term as a hedge against being too cash reliant, and the broader Fiat system. Generally speaking, for tech revolutionaries, it is now more embarrassing to not be in bitcoin because both dramatic corrections and huge gains are equally expected. However, the last decade teaches us that the gains have always beaten the corrections, so there is no long-term downside to Bitcoin anymore for publicly visible investors. If it crashes, the investors will just shrug and say, "I'm patient". That is why Saylor is so fearless with his money and his company. That is why Elon is now in. As Saylor asserts, the risk-reward ratio is now optimal.

I would also guess that Elon is waiting to see who is victorious or dominant among Eth, Dot and Ada before getting in deeper with highly useful Altcoins (not just Doge). 

I would guess that the major stock market correction that comes at the end of the US money printing will be harder on Altcoins than Bitcoin. Bitcoin is seeing institutional "diamond hands" investing and will only drop by 30-40%, but altcoins will drop by 80%. I can't wait for the crash to buy into various projects very cheap. I'm sorry, but I think you're mistaken on a few points. Your video started off good and I was liking the direction, but I simply disagree with you. First of all, the government is intensely watching the institutions right now in fear of certain big dogs planning some sort of market sell off or short. Crypto has no regulations, this can be done. Second of all, Tesla bought BTC most likely because it's a non-liquid asset which increases or decreases company value, thus inflating their stock price for SEC filings. When they sell of or not remains to be seen. Third point - for every 1 investor in BTC or another crypto, there's 50 other investors watching with a raised eyebrow calling this a tulip. The institutions know very well there's nothing justifying a 60k price and are going to take advantage of this. They are no stupid. They know what you retail investors are thinking, too. Everyone does. You all think it's going to go parabolic blah blah blah with no correction and come time September... I think a lot of the investment institutions like Goldman Sachs are going to wait for it to go to 65k or so, make a solid 5-20% on their investment, sell out, and say "buh bye" while you see the price plummet. Institutions don't roll dice like retail investors. They have PLENTY of money and aren't going to risk 5% of their portfolio as an institution to make a 200% return in a 6 month bull run. They're more calculated than that. And the institutions have enough reputation and pull in the industry to burst the bubble and do this if they want. What makes you think they wont prematurely? What makes you think everyone is waiting for massive returns here?

And BTC is *NOT* a hedge against deflation. Most investors do not think that. Gold isn't even moving up right now.

Interesting hypothesis but at the end of the day if the stock market crashed and in addition markets faltered and people stopped buying Tesla is would not matter what Tesla Balance Sheet holds i.e. FIAT/ GOLD or BITCOIN? The smart move is for the company to hold BTC as a hedge and an asset to borrow money against.

OTC trades are allowing institutions to get in without moving the price. Because they are able to do that, bitcoin is still well below 100k. They have a price target in mind and when that target is reached they will pull. If they wanted to hold for the long term they would want to move the price up as much as possible so the little people can no longer influence the price. This is exactly what I think WILL happen the next time around, but as for this time, it is 100% pump and dump. The next round, it will be so far out of peoples price range that only the 1% can afford it. You could technically hold through it but when when will the next time be? Some say the halving in 3.5 years but if that's the case I guarantee there will be a market crash, huge inflation, massive unemployment, commodity shortages or all of the above to force anyone that doesn't want to be in a homeless shelter to sell.

And don't forget about all the exchanges that will go belly up. If your crypto is on anything but a hardware wallet when this crash comes, 95% of people will lose it all to the 1% when the exchanges go down. The people have the power with crypto if they just held it ALL on hardware or some sort of keyed wallet. When you keep your crypto on an exchange you are loaning it to them to do as they please just like banks do with fiat. YOU allow them to manipulate the price by letting them hold what you view as valuable. Take that power away from them by getting it all off exchanges(banks) and the people have the power. This is what crypto was made for and meant to do but people have given up their power by allowing exchanges to come in and manipulate your store of wealth.

Its all nice saying all this so everyone understands but in the end, history shows that not enough people are going to do the right thing (use hardware wallets), and their currency and store wealth will continue to be manipulated beacuse we are either forced or tricked into it. Fiat was forced, crypto is being tricked into control. Crypto does not require exchanges, banks, or regulation, all that is and was built into it so in theory it could be a perfect currency if everyone took back their power and used hardware or keyed wallets on their phones etc.

I get the thinking but I don't buy it. Sure a crypto correction can happen at any time but there's zero reason to believe it's going to be a long term thing and the real companies like Tesla (not just trade funds) who bought in will not liquidate easily.

Specifically - the organizations that bought BTC bought it as a hedge against the USD dropping - an inevitable eventuality that scares the hell out of them and rightfully so. They all know crypto's volatility and that's why they allocated a smaller % of their cash balance than they otherwise would as a strict investment. This means they're completely prepared to ride a few volatility rides without liquidating.

As to your scenario for a market crash. It depends a lot on the cause of the crash. The most likely cause is going to be inflation of costs (in terms of USD) and loss of value for the dollar. This scenario would drive crypto higher than ever so organizations holding crypto will only liquidate to the extent necessary to satisfy operational expenses. Institutions that pull out as soon as they experience a correction will be shown as idiots and speculators rather than informed responsible investors. They were conservative to get in and they'll be conservative to get out.

Definitely there's plenty of hype that those people who piled on will run quickly. But I suspect you'll see the institutions buy into the dip and drive it up higher not unlike March of last year.

Banks interests are going down. 
Money printing is highest today which decreases its value and increased inflation. 

INR currency Inflation rate - 5.1% 
USD currency Inflation rate - 1.8%
World wide inflation - 4.7%

Meaning Currencies are losing values, government printing money like crazy & Things will be more & more expensive.

For example. 2016 it cost 2 Bitcoins to purchase latest iPhone 6 in 2020 you can buy 9 latest iPhone 12 using 1 Bitcoin. You know iPhone prices are almost double from where it started. Same goes for everything else and even gold. 

Bitcoin is deflationary, if you don't buy it on average today it'll be way more expensive in future. You won't get rich but you'll get more fiat currency in return. 

You can't get rich in short term investing in BTC but definitely increase your currency value investing in BTC.

 Shares ke jo graph hote hai na unko study krne mei hi ga*nde phat jaati hai, jo log karte hai kabhi unn se picho ki kitna time aur dimaak lagata hai ye sab seekhne mei. Naki bas 4 ya 5 hazzar rupay ke liye promotion kr do kisi chitiya app ka.

 And one thing more ye jo apps ka promotion ho raha hai , inn mei kuch apps to hai jo ki kuch countries mei ban hai. Kyunki kai baar vo apka paisa galat jagah invest krwa deti hai.

I have some bitcoin and I do think there is a future for it but my problem with it is it is clearly in a bubble right now. This is unpopular and smug to say but once the average guy on the street who knows nothing about investing, or stocks or inflation or whatever is in on something "that is a sure thing" that, " you will miss out on" then you are clearly in a bubble. it's mania and hysteria. Literally the same exact thing that happened in the mid 000's with housing. All of a sudden everyone was a developer, everyone was  a flipper, everyone knew everything about housing and it was riskless and anyone not involved was a dumbass who obviously didn't want to get rich. doesn't matter what it is, when that becomes the sentiment, you are in a bubble. there is no such thing as a sure thing investment on this earth, never was, never will be, but the majority of those involved with bitcoin aren't saying that. it's all just " well I guess you don't like money" or " enjoy living in your mums basement". If you literally have to persuade people or insult them  to get in on this thing that's a sure thing, you are just going with a crowd.... again, bubble. bitcoin hasn't even demonstrated yet what it is. some people are saying it's a currency and other's are saying it's a safe-haven asset. It can't become a proper currency until it becomes less volatile and people speculating on it have no interest in it being less volatile because they want quick gains. it can't be a widely used currency until it is stable. you can't wake up every morning and wonder if your money is worth $2000 more or less than it was when you went to bed. How could you ever pay for things like that? why would you spend money that could be worth more tomorrow. How could a business ever accurately price their goods if it changes by so much every day. one day a can of coke is worth a thousandth of a bit coin and the next day it's worth 500th of a bitcoin. So what, they re-sticker all their items every single day? how to they keep up with the conversion and the price change? until that gets sorted, it's never being widely used as a currency. So you have the speculation side, which largely rests on the price continuing to go up, when it stops there will likely be a big run on it. Also what happens to it when it gets to 21 million coins? once it hits it's ceiling it could tank because it's ceiling has been reached and that's when bubbles certainly pop. Other safe-haven assets have either history or inherent value on their side. gold and silver for example can store wealth but they also have use and 5000 years plus of history suggesting value. bitcoin has none of this just people who need to believe it's different. I mean all the reasons people distrust paper money is because it's not backed by anything? what's bitcoin backed by? less? the us dollar rightly or wrongly is backed by the emerican government and economy, bitcoin is backed by nothing. Again, I think it will have use but the clear evidence is at the moment that it's a bubble and that it's potential is all theoretical and not definite. Hence why I am suspicious of anyone claiming it's a sure thing. especially when most of the people involved seem to take a piss and dump based on what musk says on twitter. not exactly logical investing
Just like the Beanie Baby craze and the supposedly "limited production numbers" which has been abused many times in history to date now... why should we trust their word on 21mil???

Itâ€™s difficult to compare the seventeenth century Dutch gilder with the present day dollar, but reasonable to say tulips were selling for 300 to 500 thousand dollars at the top in 1635 Amsterdam. I do not know when or how the speculative bubble in Bitcoin will burst, but here are a few thoughts:
1. Warren Buffet values Bitcoin at a few dollars. He likens it to a checkbook. Just because you can use it to write a check for 50K does not make the checkbook more valuable.

2. A modern economy needs a central bank and a fractional reserve banking system. Most people do not have the capital to purchase a house, or even a car. Banks making Bitcoin loans must be reserved in Bitcoin. Thus can Bitcoin be printed.

3. Bitcoin is â€œminedâ€ using a cryptographic hash function. It takes about the same computing power to find a string of bits that hashes to the 256 bits that creates a Bitcoin as it does to finding new prime numbers. The advantage of the hash is that once such a number is claimed to be found it is easy to check. Very large numbers are difficult to factor so it is more difficult to verify a new prime. When you purchase a Bitcoin it is not much different from purchasing a prime number.

4. Blockchain is a useful and legitimate accounting method, but it adds no value, it merely makes it impossible to steal. Blockchain may be used to verify ownership of anything such as digital beanie babies, digital baseball cards, digital art, etc.

5. Elon Musk was caught in a stock fraud scheme a few years ago to boost (or maintain) Teslaâ€™s share price. Musk is not who or what you think he is. Do not follow his lead.

6. The â€œgreater foolâ€ theory of investing: Iâ€™m going to buy this because some greater fool will pay even more in future.

That Bitcoin vs Apple vs Gold argument is completely retarded.  Apple wasn't just an 'idea' that lucked out.  It has created and sold countless products, acquired assets, provided employment.  Gold is used in industry, jewelry, and considered a Tier 1 financial asset.  Bitcoin does absolutely nothing other than make you money if you sell it to someone willing to buy it for more than you.  Bitcoin is nowhere near the market cap of Apple and Gold because it has 'zero' reason 'to' have that kind of valuation.  You can't just SAY 'look at these other huge market caps.. bitcoin has all this room to grow to these sizes.'  For what reason?  And the 21 million = scarcity argument is equally dumb.  You don't mention that bitcoins can be split into satoshis.  ONE bitcoin = 100 MILLION satoshis.  How scarce is it if you start measuring bitcoins in satoshis?

It is a simple story of supply and demand, or more specifically the halfing of bitcoin mining causes a staggered bull run. Miners sell coins as fast as they get them creating a consistent sell pressure, but when this is cut in half that consistent sell pressure takes a consistent drop. First in the days and weeks before the hafling miners will stop selling  some coins they mint and start holding a percentage. For weeks or months after the halfing the horded coins will supplement the sell pressure they can create with newly minted coins. Well this is happening interest is building up around the raising value and starts to increase buy pressure. Finally the miners and speculators run out of horded coins at the same time interest is peaking resulting in the price spike we saw in December. The thing that is different this time is there are not many spectacular looking places to move your bitcoin earnings into, and major institutions are jumping on board to further increase interest and buying pressure.

Interesting video. Some counter-arguments to the points you made:

1) Bitcoin has a finite value of 21M coins. Yes - for now. There can only ever be so many coins in existence, and what happens once most of those are owned? Bitcoin is a deflating currency, no one would ever sell it when it will just go up in value. Once it becomes hard to buy bitcoin, there will be extreme temptation on the part of brokers to modify the software to create more bitcoin (and essentially print more money) so that the market can keep liquid and profits continue.

2) Bitcoin is not the revolutionary technology. *Blockchain* is. Nothing theoretically stops big finance from developing their own currencies based on this technology and displacing Bitcoin as the "market leader". In fact, major institutions are already working on this. Bitcoin is valuable currently simply because it's the most *widely adopted* crypto, but nothing makes it innately better than any of the other coins.

HERE IS A REAL EXPLANATION OF Bitcoin. It is just another version of a Stock. It goes up and down based on trades and can make or loose you money. They will tell you that it is to protect you incase a governments economy collapses. Stocks do the exact same thing already. You can buy stock with Dollars and sell it in Euros... Bitcoins price is also based on money backed by the government. If the world economy collapses so would bitcoin and the value of stocks. The reason it's price keeps going up is because people keep buying more. Once people get a little profit or they realize it's just another Stock they sell it off. When they do it causes the price to fall, just like a stock. The companies you have to use to buy and sell the coins give your transaction history to your local government, so it can't be used to hide earnings or shelter funds you already have. Originally it was popular among drug dealers and black market criminals, now that it is popular governments worldwide have forced the companies trading it to give the records to them. Using black market companies who don't turn over the info is a crime and you can be fined or arrested for tax evasion or sheltering assets if involved in a court case over another issue. Plain and simple it's just a Stock at this point and you can't legally hide the fact that your buying and selling it. So only criminals have a real use for it when it comes to hiding funds. You're much better off buying traditional stocks because eventually it will crash dramatically. It's just another bubble...

Crypto taking off so rapidly in such a short time given the market uncertainty has me conflicted. It could develop into a fantastic asset if this continues, but as soon as the media jumped on it and started promoting investing, that set off sirens in my head. May be tempted to get into it when it does inevitably have a serious, serious crash.

I see too many pressures for it to go up.  Those big institutional investors are poised for huge earnings growth and increases in free cash flows such as Square and Tesla.  Tesla is estimated to double its net income in 2021.  I imagine their 1B position could at least double.  Moreover, Africa is a rapidly growing economy. Finally, the financial services sector surrounding crypto is seeing massive influx of users.  Robinhood has more users than any, and they plan to expand the crypto offerings and have a crypto wallet associated with all accounts this year! So we have both retail and institutional investments surely to rise in 2021.

OMG you still don't fully understand how it works!

Owners buy coins before they announce it. Then there's the pump, where people buy regular sell orders from the order book. When the price reaches the owner's sell orders then they sell. A lot of people get stuck with the coins because not all of them sell at a loss. At this point the price is still higher than what it was before. Then arbitrageurs buy the coins from other exchanges and sell them on the exchange where the p&d happened. The price resettles to the original price.
